awd_titl_txt: RUI: Supporting New Efforts in Studies of Neutron-Rich Nuclides
awd_abstract_narration:
Research experience for undergraduate students is vital for their professional development and entrance into a successful career or graduate school. The nuclear physics group at Augustana College (a small, undergraduate-only, liberal arts institution located in Rock Island, Illinois) provides an active research program that involves undergraduate students in unique experiments and equipment development. This Research in Undergraduate Institutions award will support undergraduate students and the primary investigator, including support to travel to the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory (NSCL) at Michigan State University (MSU), to collaborate with others on experiments that explore nuclear structure, analyze data, and publish research results.

Experiments on exotic nuclear systems at or near the neutron drip-line are necessary to constrain modern theoretical models. Nuclides near the neutron drip-line may be produced in states that are neutron-unbound, which means that a neutron is emitted from a nuclide shortly after the nuclide is formed. In addition, the charged fragment left over after neutron emission may be in a bound excited state resulting in gamma-ray emission. A device developed by the PI and collaborators called the charged particle detector telescope (CPDT) provides the ability to detect long-lived neutron-unbound states or short-lived bound excited states of the charged fragment. The device was funded by an MRI NSF grant. Experiments studying 13Be and 28O (via 28F) with efficient detection of gamma-rays will be performed using the CPDT. Neutrons will be detected by the MoNA-LISA (Modular Neutron Array and the Large-area multi-Institutional Scintillator Array). The nuclides will be produced using the unique capabilities of NSCL. The research in this project involves analyzing and disseminating results about neutron-unbound nuclear systems from prior and new experiments. Future experiments will be proposed for the Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB), under construction at MSU, focusing on higher Z nuclides, which will require improved understanding of the CPDT to determine any upgrades needed for to the experiment setup. This project will further our current understanding of neutron-rich nuclides using the capabilities of the NSCL facility moving toward FRIB. The PI will involve undergraduate students in all aspects of the research program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The nuclear physics research group at Augustana College was supported by this grant to perform physics studies on neutron-rich nuclides with the Modular Neutron Array (MoNA Collaboration) at the Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB), formerly the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory (NSCL), on the campus of Michigan State University (MSU). Undergraduate Augustana students and the primary investigator worked on experiment design, participation and analysis, and dissemination of experimental results with investigators from the MoNA collaboration. Augustana undergraduate students engaged with graduate students, faculty, and undergraduate students from other institutions. Through this work, undergraduate students gained valuable research experience that helped them pursue their career goals or achieve acceptance into graduate school.

The Intellectual Merit of the supported work included studies of neutron-rich nuclides to improve our theoretical understanding of these systems and to maintain and develop experimental devices. Members of the Augustana research team analyzed nuclides 25,26F, 31Ne, 32Mg, and 33,34Al, produced in three different experiments. The result of these analyses was to include some of the nuclides in a future graduate student dissertation. Undergraduate Augustana students worked on the analysis of a new charged particle detector telescope (CPDT) system funded by a separate grant after it was used for the first time to search for a possible long-lived state resulting from neutron emission from 11Li. Digital data acquisition electronics were used to record data from the CPDT. Augustana undergraduates led the effort to design an analysis scheme to process the digitally recorded electronic signals from the suite of detectors, which was vital to an MSU graduate student dissertation. Finally, the Augustana research group worked on an experiment using the Los Alamos Neutron Science Center (LANSCE) to better understand inelastic interactions with 12C and tested a prototype for a future neutron detector at Triangle Universities Nuclear Laboratory (TUNL).

The primary investigator and undergraduate students were co-authors on published papers and multiple talks at the April or Division of Nuclear Physics Meetings of the American Physical Society to disseminate results. Most talks were presented by undergraduate students, which is an important educational aspect of the research.

The Broader Impacts of the work were training Augustana undergraduate students by engaging them in research at a top-notch nuclear physics facility and collaborating on analyses with researchers at MSU and the MoNA collaboration. The Augustana team worked on analyses with multiple institutions and graduate students within the collaboration, which helped analyses move forward to publication. Ten undergraduates participated in this work. All students received training in basic research skills, nuclear physics, programming in ROOT, GEANT4, C++, Linux, and Python, and experimental equipment for their project. Students gained presentation and networking skills by going to national conferences. Finally, most student participants engaged in efforts to support and retain Augustana STEM students by participating in a peer mentoring program.

As a direct result of the skills, knowledge and network built while working on this research, all ten students remain dedicated to pursuing careers in physics and engineering. Two of the graduated students are performing nuclear physics research for their PhD at MSU or the University of Washington in St. Louis, four students are in STEM careers, and the remaining four are applying to STEM graduate school programs.
